name: Woodchuck
description: It has a stocky body, short legs and tail, and small, rounded ears. Its coloration varies from gray-brown to cinnamon-rust. The guard hairs on its back have white tips, giving it a grizzled appearance.
spread_note: From southern Alaska through Canada to the southern USA
food_note: Mainly grass and herbs, also leaves and shoots
proportions: Body length 35–50 cm, tail length 10–15 cm, weight 3–5 kg
reproduction: The female is pregnant for 31–32 days and gives birth to a single litter (usually 3–5 young) per year.
attractions: It’s a renowned “sleeper”—spending over 6 months a year in hibernation, during which its body temperature drops to just 2°C! To survive this long period, it builds up fat reserves by late summer, weighing up to 2 kg more in fall than in spring. Unlike the European alpine marmot, it is not social.
breeding: Woodchucks were seen at the zoo from 1974–1987. After a break, the current animals arrived in 2012 and successfully bred their first offspring in 2013.
